course.title: Software Architecture and Design
course.prereq: CSC340H (Information Systems Analysis and Design), CSC378H (Data Structures and Algorithm Analysis)
course.text: Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software, Gamma et. al. Addison-Wesley (Professional Computing Series), 1995 ISBN 0-201-63361-2

course.title: Formal Methods of Program Design
course.text: E.C.R. Hehner, A Practical Theory of Programming, second edition, Springer, 2003

course.title: Software Engineering
course.prereq: CSC340, CSC378, or equivalent
course.text: Hans van Vliet, Software Engineering - Principles and Practice (2nd ed.), John Wiley, 2000.

course.title: Automated Verification
course.prereq: Graduate standing or permission of instructor. Experience with model-checking and other formal methods, although helpful, is not necessary. However, the course assumes familiarity with basic computer science concepts: relations and functions; boolean and first-order logic (from undergrad discrete-math course), and finite-state machines. You are also expected to have basic knowledge of concurrency. The course includes a number of theoretical and engineering aspects.
course.text: 'Model Checking', by Clarke, Grumberg, Peled, 1999, MIT Press.

course.title: Operating Systems
course.prereq: CSC258H1, CSC209H1/knowledge of concurrent programming
course.text: Applied Operating System Concepts (Windows XP Update), A. Silberschatz, P. B. GAlvin and G. Gagne, Wiley (2003).

course.title: Computer Networks
course.text: Layered network architecture, ARQ retransmission strategies, delay models for data networks, multiaccess communication, routing, congestion control, addressing.

course.title: Topics in the Theory of Distributed Systems
Topics in Mobile and Pervasive Computing
course.prereq: Basic understanding of operating system principles and knowledge of network programming

course.title: High-Performance Scientific Computing
course.prereq: Elementary calculus: Taylor series, Rolle's theorem, mean value theorem, graphs of functions, continuity, convergence, de l' Hospital's rule, etc.

course.title: Numerical Software
course.prereq: Any previous numerical methods, numerical analysis, or scientific computing course.
course.text: The Engineering of Numerical Software, by Webb Miller, Prentice-Hall, 1984. Republished by the Custom Printing Dept., UofT Bookstore.

course.title: Introduction to Computational Complexity
course.text: Theory of Computational Complexity, Ding-Zhu Du and Ker-I KO

course.title: Computability and Logic
course.prereq: CSC 364/MAT247

course.title: Automata Theory
course.prereq: Some knowledge of computability theory is recommended.
course.text: Introduction to the Theory of Computation, by Michael Sipser

course.title: Expander graphs and their Applications
course.prereq: This course has no prerequisites.

course.title: Machine Learning Theory
course.prereq: The only prerequisite for this course is the equivalent of CS364 (undergraduate complexity
course.text: An Introduction to Computational Learning Theory by Kearns and Vazirani.

course.title: Finite Model Theory and Descriptive Complexity
course.prereq: being familiar with the basic notions of first-order propositional and predicate logic (if you took an undergrad logic.
course.text: L. Libkin, Elements of Finite Model Theory, 293pp, 1st draft

course.title: Dynamic Data Structure
course.prereq: A good undergraduate course in data structures (that focussed on correctness and complexity).

course.title: Introduction to Computational Linguistics
course.prereq: a course in AI, knowledge of LISP, or Prolog; or a major in Linguistics; or permission of the instructor.
course.text: Jurafsky, Daniel, Martin, James H. Speech and Language Processing. Prentice-Hall, 2000.

course.title: Introduction to Knowledge Representation
course.prereq: a course in AI and working knowledge of LISP and PROLOG
course.text: A hardcopy of the text for the course, a draft of a book by Brachman and Levesque, will be distributed in class.

course.title: Computational Vision I
course.prereq: MAT235 and CSC324, or equivalents
course.text: E. Trucco and A. Verri, Introductory Techniques for 3D Computer Vision, Prentice-Hall, 1998 (ISBN 0-13-261108-2).

course.title: Computer Graphics
course.prereq: proficiency in C, and preferably C++.
course.text: F.S. Hill, Jr. Computer Graphics Using OpenGL, Second Edition, Prentice Hall, 2001.

course.title: Computer Graphics
course.prereq: proficiency in C, and preferably C++.
course.text: F.S. Hill, Jr. Computer Graphics Using OpenGL, Second Edition, Prentice Hall, 2001.

course.title: Machine Learning
course.text: Elements of Statistical Learning, Hastie, Tibsshirani, Friedman.

course.title: Topics in Computer Graphics: Machine Learning
course.prereq: CS grads or instructor permission
course.text: Information Theory, Inference, and Learning Algorithms, by David MacKay

course.title: Software Architecture And Design
course.prereq: CSC340H (Information Systems Analysis and Design), CSC378H (Data Structures and Algorithm Analysis).

course.title: Requirement Engineering
course.prereq: CSC408 or permission of the instructor.

course.title: Software Engineering
course.prereq: CSC340, CSC378, or equivalent

course.title: Language Processors
course.prereq: Courses in data structures and programming languages.

course.title: Computer System Modelling
course.prereq: Solid knowledge of basic probability theory.

course.title: Matrix Calculations
course.prereq: calculus, numerical linear algebra, interpolation, some knowledge of PDEs, programming preferably in FORTRAN.

course.title: Theoretical Aspects of Concurrent Programming
course.prereq: This course will be concerned with various aspects of the theory underlying parallel architectures and concurrent programming. The following is a tentative list of topics: formalisms for expressing concurrency including flow expressions, path expressions, Petri nets; relative power of synchronization primitives; critical section solutions; the database consistency problem; language features for concurrent programming; e.g. monitors; proving the correctness of concurrent programs; mapping concurrent programs onto parallel architectures.

course.title: Topics in Cryptography
course.prereq: An introduction to cryptography including rigorous definitions of security, a presentation of the number theoretic background, and applications of number theory to various cryptographic problems.

course.title: Computer Graphics
course.prereq: proficiency in C, and preferably C++.

course.title: Computer Graphics
course.prereq: proficiency in C, and preferably C++.

course.title: Natural Language Computing
course.prereq: csc228, sta220/250/257 or equivalents

course.title: Constraint Satisfaction Problems
course.prereq: an introductory AI course (CSC384 or equivalent) or permission of the instructor

course.title: Topics in Computer Graphics: Artificial Life
Computational Vision II
course.prereq: CSC484 or equivalent, and CSC2503

course.title: The Business of Software
course.prereq: CSC2204 (Operating Systems) or equivalent

course.title: Topics in Computational Linguistics
course.prereq: CSC2501(485) or permission of instructor Possible Preparatory Reading: Review the papers in recent issues of Computational Linguistics, and Proceedings of the annual conferences of the Association for Computational Linguistics.

course.title: Visual Modeling
course.prereq: CSC2503, 2504, or permission of instructor.

course.title: Computation in Neural Networks
course.prereq: Some knowledge of calculus and linear algebra.
